name: Ace Hotel Portland

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Excellent location and good customer service. The hotel is going for a kind of warehouse, war, prison feel. We booked late and so had to have a room with 3 singles instead of a double. Room clean but it felt a bit like a prison cell as there are no frills at all. Maybe other rooms are better. TV was very small and had very had reception. We shared a bathroom which was no problem at all, it seemed like we were the only ones using it. Good for a quirky stay, but would not recommend for a luxurious holiday.
reviews.title: Trendy and good location but room a bit like a prison cell

reviews.text: Completely loved our stay, my dog was welcome, I felt like I was staying at a friends house rather than an hotel. Cute decor! We were upgraded to suite. Staff was super helpful and friendly and we were even able to bikes! The Ace is lovely enough to offer band rates and it was a pleasant change to all the other corporate chain hotels out there. Consider me a new member of the Ace Hotel chain fanclub!
reviews.title: Hip, cool, pet friendly, The world needs more Ace hotels!

reviews.text: We're in our fifties, have travelled extensively, staying in accomodations ranging from REAL youth hostels to luxury hotels. It was clear from check-in that we were not this hotel's target audience. Our expensive and very tiny room boasted a platform bed with futon in need of either turning or replacement, a dripping faucet in the sink, and a questionable odor from the none-too-clean carpet. When we mentioned these problems to the front desk we were met with polite condescension, as if these were mere corporeal concerns that could be transcended by plugging in our earbuds. Ice this scenario with an uncovered bulb in the ceiling and clamp on work lights for bedside reading and you have the perfect Portland cupcake; self absorbed, affected, cool only if your concept of cool includes discomfort. I find it very amusing that all of the light bulbs are incandescent, not at CFL in sight-how retro! Stay here only if you want a SRO experience with 'groovy' wall treatments.
reviews.title: This hotel gives Portland a bad name

reviews.text: Good location but loud rooms and barely got sleep due to noise of street outside and people talking loudly in room next door. Worst of all was the uncaring and pretentious service as I asked for help with directions and the front desk guy shrugged his shoulders and told me to figure it out. It would have been nice to have looked it up for me. The room was not nearly as 'cool' or hip as advertised and did not feel it was worth the price. I liked the lobby and coffee shop.
reviews.title: Fancy youth hostel with pretentious service and loud rooms

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Ace hotel was a great find. It has a cool vibe, with people hanging out on their laptops drinking coffee on squishy sofas in the lobby. And our room was fabulous! Very large, with a lounge area and more squishy sofas and a huge and comfy bed. The bath was a roll-top and a rather complicated shower (great once we figured out how to make it hot!), and the best thing was that you could slide back the door and watch TV from the bat - the ultimate multi-tasking!
reviews.title: Fantastic!

reviews.text: The Ace Hotel Portland is a discrete bohemian retreat in a fantastic food city. We stayed four nights in a large room with sofa, comfortable bed, natural light and a turntable. At first we were a little taken back as it wasn’t the resort style of the PS Ace hotel and swim club but more of a city hotel. The place worked out perfectly with some very cool attributes that force you to be social rather than hide out in your room and order room service. So our room was very much a retreat so in the morning put on Super tramp on the turntable and pull the day together. You have to go down to Stumptown coffee, Clyde Commons or out side for a smoke. So it forces you to engage Portland. The Hotel is close to the best restaurants and bars so you walk to everything. The design of the hotel is bohemian-lux with a fantastic bed and linen, excellent bathing products and clean. The Ace chain is not for every one but it’s grown on me if we want to just relax with cool people.
reviews.title: The Ace rocks Portland
Awesome minimalist hotel
reviews.text: Great location just inside the Pearl District!
This hotel is so uniquely decorated. The wall in our room was covered in Italian newspapers and there were trunks stacked up for the nightstand.
reviews.title: You feel cooler the minute you walk in

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Be sure to request a room with a private bath if that is important to you (there are cheaper rooms with a community bath.
reviews.title: Hip and fun

reviews.text: There are two main social areas within the hotel: (1) a study/reading nook (2) lobby that are a popular spot for locals to hang.
reviews.title: Trendy hotel, downtown Portland

reviews.text: If I were 22 years old and looking for a cool place in central Portland, this would be it. Well, I am 40 and went there for business. I did not sleep from the hours of midnight until 2 am because of all of the street noise right below my room. The hotel does have its Portland too-hip-to-be-cool charm, with a great restaurant and great coffee shop onsite. However, if you go and you are a person who goes to a hotel to get some sleep, make sure you get a room that is not in the front (which apparently a lot of rooms are). I would say there was a group of 20 bar-goers directly below my window who made a ton of noise and kept me up. I am a city dweller to begin with, but this was an outrageous amount of noise. Definitely not a place for a business traveler, and pricey for what the room was.
reviews.title: Funky hotel, not for business traveler

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I loved the decor in this room, it was fun to come home to at the end of each day and a nice place to hang out. The hotel is in a pretty convenient spot, walking distance to everywhere we wanted to go. The only downside was that every morning at around 5am a very noisy truck would pull up outside our window and collect all the empty bottles from somewhere, with much crashing and banging. But, it was easy enough to go back to sleep again after that.
reviews.title: I would definitely stay here again

reviews.text: We stayed at the Ace Hotel only one night- I wish we didn't have relatives in Portland because I would have loved to stay there the entire time! at first I was a little skeptical- bathrooms down the hall and "bunk bed" style for the 3 of us. But my partner had heard about it and wanted to stay, so I booked. My son, once he saw the room, also was skeptical. But- the beds were INCREDIBLY comfortable- we all slept excellent. There were plenty of bathrooms- even though they were down the hall, it was very "old world" and became fun. The products the hotel has for showering (Malin and Goetz) were great. for example, they stok the showers with the cilantro hair conditioner- it sounds odd- but you want to stay in the shower for the smells! They have one of the most inviting lobbys with a coffee shop just off the side, and a huge table surrounded by some of the most comfortable chairs- filled with people reading, talking, and working on laptops. The staff were as nice and efficient as anyone could ask for. It was truly a wonderful experience.
reviews.title: What fun we had

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: So, I loved this hotel. It is very much the style that I like. Take a look at the website and you kind of get the idea of what it's about. The place has definitely got a unique feel to it. I found the staff to be extremely helpful. Our flight from the East Coast was canceled and our arrival was delayed by over 7 hours, but the people at the front desk were more than willing to make adjustments to my reservation.
reviews.title: Hip hotel which may appeal to particular demographic

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were on the third floor (rm 308). It was like a studio room with the shower in close proximity to the bed. Sounds weird, but I liked the layout for the small space that it was. Room was super clean. I liked how the snack bar were items (mostly) local to the Portland area.
reviews.title: I Think I Could Live at the Ace

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at the Ace for five nights at the end of September and loved every minute of it. The staff were friendly and approachable, the lobby and mezzanine seating area (with free Wi Fi) comfortable and hip and the Stumptown coffee house next door a great place to grab an early morning coffee or late night cocoa. I had the best cup of tea I have ever had in the States here. The room was pretty basic but in a cool hostel chic way with nice toiletries and the bed was the most comfortable ever! I would definitely stay here again and would recommend to anyone after a hip place to stay in lovely Portland. Oh, and the deli next door was great too.
reviews.title: It's Ace!

reviews.text: The only tip I would offer if you're out and about during the day is not to bother paying $20 per day for the car parking. Parking in central Portland is free between 7pm and 8am!
reviews.title: Utilitarian chic

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I went to PDX for a food and beer extravaganza, and the Ace made for a perfect base camp. Loved the charcoal gray walls, claw foot tub, murals and olive green wool blankets. And location is stellar right next to Stumptown coffee, a great deli and major buses and tram. Unlike other reviewers who met aloof staff, I found the front desk help to be friendly and attentive. I even called once from the road when I couldn't find a restaurant, and they double-checked the address for me.
reviews.title: if only being hip was all it took to be a good hotel

reviews.text: If you stay here, do check out the neighboring restaurant Clyde Common's happy hour, which includes great deals on food and craft cocktails. These are bartenders who wax poetic about making their own bitters and possessing limited edition whiskeys from the Prohibition era. But the friendliness tends to outweigh the attitude, and they make some fantastic drinks customized to your preferences. Case in point: a Jim Beam Black, Laphroaig, cherry heering, and orange bitters garnished with an orange peel served on the rocks to satisfy my smoky, citrus craving.
reviews.title: Very Cool Hotel, We're Talking Different!!

reviews.text: I was in Portland for the NW Music Festival and wanted to stay someplace fun. The Ace Hotel looked like an interesting place to stay. I took for granted that it would also be a good hotel. If I could sleep and sit on hipness it would have been a great place to stay. The room was uncomfortable. The bed was a futon mattress on the floor. The floor and bedding looked dirty. The only place to sit in the room was a ratty, old school style chair with a torn up vinyl seat. Me and my boyfriend had fun playing old vinyl records on the turn table but again, not really what I'm looking for in hotel accommodations. .
reviews.title: couldn't ask for more

description: A friendly, urbanized version of the welcoming country inn along a country lane.
